ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: The class was conducted entirely as a virtual seminar.
Prof. Cohn was available to meet individually over Zoom to discuss things from class.
In-person class would be the best, but the virtual setting still works for us to learn a lot of things from the class.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: My skills as a music theorist grew exponentially during this course! I feel like I have the tools to understand most 19th century classical/Romantic music, and I have really enjoyed getting to know more of the repertoire of this period, especially Schubert, Brahms, and Wagner. I learned a lot about ways to analyze music outside of Roman numeral analysis, and I got a lot better at writing music analysis papers and making music analysis presentations. The primary topics covered included chromatic motifs, harmonic dualism, and the Tonnetz (transformational theory). If you take the course, you will be blown away by how much you learn. I haven't looked at a piece of music the same since.
I learned a lot of modes of analysis relating to 19th century music! It helped me understand (and develop) tools to study this music. Lots of analytical thinking.

I appreciated the opportunity to learn new things, including Tonnez, Cube Dance, and Cube Tower. Deeper observations for harmonies, harmonic progressions, chromatic passages, key relations, structures, and text-paintings gave me a lot of insights for each piece we studied in the class.  His class and teaching encouraged us to see the details "precisely" and that helps to understand each music better. Also, I personally learned teaching techniques from him- how to encourage students and how to grow them.
Exposure to many analytical tools for understanding romantic-era music; practice reading scores in depth
Understanding of the theoretical means used to analyze 19th-century harmony, starting with Roman numeral analysis and ending with graphic and three-dimensional representations of tonal space.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Cohn did an excellent job teaching a varied array of topics in 19th century music theory. All of the teaching methods are very effective. My only criticism is that we covered a pretty limited range of composers, which is inherent in the nature of the course, but the title of the class might have been better as "Music Theory of Schubert, Wagner, and Brahms."

The strengths were the ability to discuss things together in a small group, and get immediate feedback on the way we think through issues. The weakness is that there was quite a variety of levels of comfort with analysis within the class, which at times made work together difficult.

Zoom setting was not easy for me (in general, for all other class), but I appreciated his constant help through emails and individual zoom meetings to be able to follow the class. That was a big help.
Rick's a great instructor and you hear a lot of good music. The amount of work was more than I expected, however.
It's a very good course. I felt like everything had a place in the curriculum, and that everything belonged in its sequential order.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The class worked perfectly well over Zoom. Professor Cohn was able to share his computer sound and play the piano from his office, so everything seemed pretty much as it would in a normal year.

In-class musical examples worked, and discussions on Zoom were perfectly fine. The breakout rooms were great! It would have been nice to have some in-person component, perhaps one-on-one meetings to get together to discuss things.
I appreciated his setting the rule for the class - the camera should be on during the class. This rule helped us a lot to focus and pay attention during the class.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would 100% recommend this course, especially if you're serious about music theory or composition. This is one of the best classes I've taken at Yale with one of the best professors I've studied with so far. Professor Cohn is very modest, but he is one of the most influential music theorists alive today, and he has practically invented most of the theory that you will learn about. You will learn so much about music theory that you won't be able to believe that you tried to analyze music before taking the class. For me as a composer, the course has given me an incredibly valuable toolset of new techniques to use when thinking about harmonies, and my compositions have immediately reflected these influences. The workload of the class can be fairly high when the papers come around (be prepared to write five papers, with many graphs), but I think that it's worth it. If you pay attention in class and spend a decent amount of time analyzing the piece, the papers will write themselves in no time. Especially if you're interesting music theory as a potential career, learning how to properly write analysis papers and make analysis presentations is super valuable; making graphs is tedious but also pretty enjoyable if you're into that kind of thing.
Yes! You learn a lot about the structure of a lot of music from a very interesting professor. Totally worth it.
Yes. We learned a lot of things from this class. It is not just an informative lecture/class, but we had opportunities to think, share, study, and learn with the class/group together.

Yes -- it's a relatively harmless way to get one's advanced theory requirement. I'm perhaps the wrong person to ask, since I'm not particularly enthusiastic about the Romantic period (not a whole lot by way of early music theories in this department), but overall I felt like I learned a lot.
